member.name: T:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager
member.summary: Manages pools of objects.

remarks.para: There are two pools managed in here. The small pool contains same-sized buffers that are handed to streams as they write more data.

For scenarios that need to call , the large pool contains buffers of various sizes, all multiples/exponentials of (1 MB by default). They are split by size to avoid overly-wasteful buffer usage. There should be far fewer 8 MB buffers than 1 MB buffers, for example.

member.summary: Number of bytes in large pool not currently in use.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.LargePoolInUseSize
member.summary: Number of bytes currently in use by streams from the large pool.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options
member.summary: Parameters for customizing the behavior of

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the pooled blocks. This must be greater than 0.
member.remarks: The default size 131,072 (128KB)

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.LargeBufferMultiple
member.summary: Each large buffer will be a multiple exponential of this value
member.remarks: The default value is 1,048,576 (1MB)

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.MaximumBufferSize
member.summary: Buffer beyond this length are not pooled.
member.remarks: The default value is 134,217,728 (128MB)

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.MaximumSmallPoolFreeBytes
member.summary: Maximum number of bytes to keep available in the small pool.

remarks.para: Trying to return buffers to the pool beyond this limit will result in them being garbage collected.
The default value is 0, but all users should set a reasonable value depending on your application's memory requirements.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.MaximumLargePoolFreeBytes
member.summary: Maximum number of bytes to keep available in the large pools.

remarks.para: Trying to return buffers to the pool beyond this limit will result in them being garbage collected.
The default value is 0, but all users should set a reasonable value depending on your application's memory requirements.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.UseExponentialLargeBuffer
member.summary: Whether to use the exponential allocation strategy (see documentation).
member.remarks: The default value is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.MaximumStreamCapacity
member.summary: Maximum stream capacity in bytes. Attempts to set a larger capacity will result in an exception.
member.remarks: The default value of 0 indicates no limit.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.GenerateCallStacks
member.summary: Whether to save call stacks for stream allocations. This can help in debugging. It should NEVER be turned on generally in production.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.AggressiveBufferReturn
member.summary: Whether dirty buffers can be immediately returned to the buffer pool.

remarks.para: When is called on a stream and creates a single large buffer, if this setting is enabled, the other blocks will be returned to the buffer pool immediately.

Note when enabling this setting that the user is responsible for ensuring that any buffer previously retrieved from a stream which is subsequently modified is not used after modification (as it may no longer be valid).

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.ThrowExceptionOnToArray
member.summary: Causes an exception to be thrown if is ever called.
member.remarks: Calling defeats the purpose of a pooled buffer. Use this property to discover code that is calling . If this is set and is called, a NotSupportedException will be thrown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.ZeroOutBuffer
member.summary: Zero out buffers on allocation and before returning them to the pool.
member.remarks: Setting this to true causes a performance hit and should only be set if one wants to avoid accidental data leaks.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Creates a new object with the most common options.
member.param: Size of the blocks in the small pool.
Size of the large buffer multiple
Maximum poolable buffer size.
Maximum bytes to hold in the small pool.
Maximum bytes to hold in each of the large pools.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes the memory manager with the default block/buffer specifications. This pool may have unbounded growth unless you modify .

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.#ctor(Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.Options)
member.summary: Initializes the memory manager with the given block requiredSize.
member.param: Object specifying options for stream behavior.
member.exception: is not a positive number, or is not a positive number, or is less than options.BlockSize, or is negative, or is negative, or is not a multiple/exponential of .

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetBlock
member.summary: Removes and returns a single block from the pool.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetLargeBuffer(System.Int64,System.Guid,System.String)
member.summary: Returns a buffer of arbitrary size from the large buffer pool. This buffer will be at least the requiredSize and always be a multiple/exponential of largeBufferMultiple.
member.param: The minimum length of the buffer.
Unique ID for the stream.
The tag of the stream returning this buffer, for logging if necessary.
member.returns: A buffer of at least the required size.
member.exception: Requested array size is larger than the maximum allowed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.ReturnLargeBuffer(System.Byte[],System.Guid,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the buffer to the large pool.
member.param: The buffer to return.
Unique stream ID.
The tag of the stream returning this buffer, for logging if necessary.
member.exception: buffer.Length is not a multiple/exponential of (it did not originate from this pool).

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.ReturnBlocks(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Byte[]},System.Guid,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the blocks to the pool.
member.param: Collection of blocks to return to the pool.
Unique Stream ID.
The tag of the stream returning these blocks, for logging if necessary.
member.exception: contains buffers that are the wrong size (or null) for this memory manager.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.ReturnBlock(System.Byte[],System.Guid,System.String)
member.summary: Returns a block to the pool.
member.param: Block to return to the pool.
Unique Stream ID.
The tag of the stream returning this, for logging if necessary.
member.exception: is the wrong size for this memory manager.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with no tag and a default initial capacity.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.Guid)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with no tag and a default initial capacity.
member.param: A unique identifier which can be used to trace usages of the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and a default initial capacity.
member.param: A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.Guid,System.String)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and a default initial capacity.
member.param: A unique identifier which can be used to trace usages of the stream.
A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Int64)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and at least the given capacity.
member.param: A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The minimum desired capacity for the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.Guid,System.String,System.Int64)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and at least the given capacity.
member.param: A unique identifier which can be used to trace usages of the stream.
A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The minimum desired capacity for the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.Guid,System.String,System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and at least the given capacity, possibly using a single contiguous underlying buffer.
member.remarks: Retrieving a which provides a single contiguous buffer can be useful in situations where the initial size is known and it is desirable to avoid copying data between the smaller underlying buffers to a single large one. This is most helpful when you know that you will always call on the underlying stream.
member.param: A unique identifier which can be used to trace usages of the stream.
A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The minimum desired capacity for the stream.
Whether to attempt to use a single contiguous buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStreamManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieve a new object with the given tag and at least the given capacity, possibly using a single contiguous underlying buffer.
member.remarks: Retrieving a which provides a single contiguous buffer can be useful in situations where the initial size is known and it is desirable to avoid copying data between the smaller underlying buffers to a single large one. This is most helpful when you know that you will always call on the underlying stream.
member.param: A tag which can be used to track the source of the stream.
The minimum desired capacity for the stream.
Whether to attempt to use a single contiguous buffer.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream
member.summary: MemoryStream implementation that deals with pooling and managing memory streams which use potentially large buffers.
member.remarks:
This class works in tandem with the to supply MemoryStream-derived objects to callers, while avoiding these specific problems:
LOH allocations Since all large buffers are pooled, they will never incur a Gen2 GC
Memory wasteA standard memory stream doubles its size when it runs out of room. This leads to continual memory growth as each stream approaches the maximum allowed size.
Memory copying Each time a MemoryStream grows, all the bytes are copied into new buffers. This implementation only copies the bytes when is called.
Memory fragmentation By using homogeneous buffer sizes, it ensures that blocks of memory can be easily reused.
The stream is implemented on top of a series of uniformly-sized blocks. As the stream's length grows, additional blocks are retrieved from the memory manager. It is these blocks that are pooled, not the stream object itself.
The biggest wrinkle in this implementation is when is called. This requires a single contiguous buffer. If only a single block is in use, then that block is returned. If multiple blocks are in use, we retrieve a larger buffer from the memory manager. These large buffers are also pooled, split by size--they are multiples/exponentials of a chunk size (1 MB by default).
Once a large buffer is assigned to the stream the small blocks are NEVER again used for this stream. All operations take place on the large buffer. The large buffer can be replaced by a larger buffer from the pool as needed. All blocks and large buffers are maintained in the stream until the stream is disposed (unless AggressiveBufferReturn is enabled in the stream manager).
A further wrinkle is what happens when the stream is longer than the maximum allowable array length under .NET. This is allowed when only blocks are in use, and only the Read/Write APIs are used. Once a stream grows to this size, any attempt to convert it to a single buffer will result in an exception. Similarly, if a stream is already converted to use a single larger buffer, then it cannot grow beyond the limits of the maximum allowable array size.
Any method that modifies the stream has the potential to throw an OutOfMemoryException, either because the stream is beyond the limits set in RecyclableStreamManager, or it would result in a buffer larger than the maximum array size supported by .NET.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.blocks
member.summary: All of these blocks must be the same size.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.dirtyBuffers
member.summary: This list is used to store buffers once they're replaced by something larger. This is for the cases where you have users of this class that may hold onto the buffers longer than they should and you want to prevent race conditions which could corrupt the data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.largeBuffer
member.summary: This is only set by GetBuffer() if the necessary buffer is larger than a single block size, or on construction if the caller immediately requests a single large buffer.
member.remarks: If this field is non-null, it contains the concatenation of the bytes found in the individual blocks. Once it is created, this (or a larger) largeBuffer will be used for the life of the stream.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Id
member.summary: Unique identifier for this stream across its entire lifetime.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Tag
member.summary: A temporary identifier for the current usage of this stream.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.MemoryManager
member.summary: Gets the memory manager being used by this stream.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.DisposeStack
member.summary: Call stack of the call. It is only set if is true, which should only be in debugging situations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Finalize
member.summary: The finalizer will be called when a stream is not disposed properly.
member.remarks: Failing to dispose indicates a bug in the code using streams. Care should be taken to properly account for stream lifetime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the memory used by this stream back to the pool.
member.param: Whether we're disposing (true), or being called by the finalizer (false).

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Close
member.summary: Equivalent to Dispose.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the capacity.

remarks.para: Capacity is always in multiples of the memory manager's block size, unless the large buffer is in use. Capacity never decreases during a stream's lifetime. Explicitly setting the capacity to a lower value than the current value will have no effect. This is because the buffers are all pooled by chunks and there's little reason to allow stream truncation.
Writing past the current capacity will cause to automatically increase, until MaximumStreamCapacity is reached.
If the capacity is larger than int.MaxValue, then InvalidOperationException will be thrown. If you anticipate using larger streams, use the property instead.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Capacity64
member.summary: Returns a 64-bit version of capacity, for streams larger than int.MaxValue in length.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Length
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes written to this stream.
member.remarks: If the buffer has already been converted to a large buffer, then the maximum length is limited by the maximum allowed array length in .NET.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Position
member.summary: Gets the current position in the stream.
member.exception: Stream is in large-buffer mode, but an attempt was made to set the position past the maximum allowed array length.
member.remarks: If the buffer has already been converted to a large buffer, then the maximum length (and thus position) is limited by the maximum allowed array length in .NET.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanRead
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently read.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently seek.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanTimeout
member.summary: Always false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Whether the stream can currently write.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetBuffer
member.summary: Returns a single buffer containing the contents of the stream. The buffer may be longer than the stream length.
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Doing a after calling GetBuffer invalidates the buffer. The old buffer is held onto until is called, but the next time GetBuffer is called, a new buffer from the pool will be required.
member.exception: stream is too large for a contiguous buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.CopyToAsync(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Asynchronously reads all the bytes from the current position in this stream and writes them to another stream.
member.param: The stream to which the contents of the current stream will be copied.
This parameter is ignored.
The token to monitor for cancellation requests.
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous copy operation.
member.exception: Either the current stream or the destination stream is disposed.
The current stream does not support reading, or the destination stream does not support writing.
member.remarks: Similarly to MemoryStream's behavior, CopyToAsync will adjust the source stream's position by the number of bytes written to the destination stream, as a Read would do.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.Advance(System.Int32)
member.summary: Notifies the stream that bytes were written to the buffer returned by or . Seeks forward by bytes.
member.remarks: You must request a new buffer after calling Advance to continue writing more data and cannot write to a previously acquired buffer.
member.param: How many bytes to advance.
member.exception: is larger than the size of the previously requested buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetMemory(System.Int32)
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Calling Write(), GetBuffer(), TryGetBuffer(), Seek(), GetLength(), Advance(), or setting Position after calling GetMemory() invalidates the memory.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetSpan(System.Int32)
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Calling Write(), GetBuffer(), TryGetBuffer(), Seek(), GetLength(), Advance(), or setting Position after calling GetSpan() invalidates the span.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetWritableBuffer(System.Int32)
member.summary: When callers to GetSpan() or GetMemory() request a buffer that is larger than the remaining size of the current block this method return a temp buffer. When Advance() is called, that temp buffer is then copied into the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.GetReadOnlySequence
member.summary: Returns a sequence containing the contents of the stream.
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Calling Write(), GetMemory(), GetSpan(), Dispose(), or Close() after calling GetReadOnlySequence() invalidates the sequence.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.TryGetBuffer(System.ArraySegment{System.Byte}@)
member.summary: Returns an ArraySegment that wraps a single buffer containing the contents of the stream.
member.param: An ArraySegment containing a reference to the underlying bytes.
member.returns: Returns if a buffer can be returned; otherwise, .

member.name: M:Microsoft.IO.RecyclableMemoryStream.ToArray
member.summary: Returns a new array with a copy of the buffer's contents. You should almost certainly be using combined with the to access the bytes in this stream. Calling ToArray will destroy the benefits of pooled buffers, but it is included for the sake of completeness.
member.exception: The current object disallows ToArray calls.
The length of the stream is too long for a contiguous array.
